Articles.Content:
Building an Eve biome hopper. Horizontal take off with wings, twin Vector engines. put the nose in the air and you can get an Ap of 120/140 km, and come down a quarter of a planet away, on Kerbin, I figure that means about a sixth of Eve. Its an Intercontinental Ballistic Airplane. My question is about lower- slower flight.

What is my best strategy for flying an overpowered plane that goes through fuel so quickly?

Short bursts of full throttle followed by long periods of gliding?  Or a small amount of continuous thrust?

Subsonic and low? or climb to 7 km and bust the sound barrier?  - and then glide? but for how long? down to Mach 1, or down to stall speed?

So many options!

Probably the best thing to do on Eve is to climb to around 40 or 50 km, build up a lot of speed, and then use gliding for distance. Eve's atmosphere is so thick that it makes more sense to use it as a source of lift, rather than avoiding it using a suborbital hop. The best way to do that probably involves feathering the throttle, although the only real way to find out is by experimentation. If I had to hazard a guess, though, I would say using a low throttle and aerodynamic lift is probably more efficient than muscling your way through the atmosphere using a high throttle.

As far as optimal max speed goes, I'd say capping it out around ~Mach 5 is probably for the best. That's the place in the supersonic regime where drag is the worst. What you should definitely not do is hang out in the range from Mach 0.8 to Mach 1.1, since drag is really high in that regime.

For landing... whatever works for your plane. Every aircraft is different. Some can land at their stall speed, some can't even land unless the engines are running. It really depends.

I've got a plane on Eve. A part of it can even get back home. Which means it's a little bit ridiculous that it can only make, like 30 km hops when it's actually there. It's not easy to fly there but then nothing about Eve is easy. 

The problem is the soupy air plus the heavy gravity. Flown like I would fly it on Kerbin, the air grabs it, slows it to a halt, and the gravity slams it to the ground. So just to land I have to come down at a pretty steep angle, keeping my velocity around 60 m/s, then flare up at which point it'll very rapidly slow down to about 35 and touch down. To hop, I just burn upward at 45-60 degrees as far as my fuel will take me, then glide back down. No way I'll get up to 40 km or Mach anything much -- best I can do is maybe 15-20 km. And I'm packing pretty serious engines.

I.e.: it works, it's certainly possible to make something that works better than my first attempt at an Eve plane, it's difficult, and your biome hops will likely be hops, not glorious sweeping arcs.
